awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Admixture mapping of a hybrid zone to test Tinbergen's emancipation hypothesis
awd_abstract_narration:
Understanding how genes cause the behavioral traits of different species to be different is a major goal of evolutionary biology.  This project seeks to test the emancipation hypothesis proposed by Tinbergen 60 years ago to understand how a novel behavior arises by using a hybrid zone between two species of hummingbirds. The novel behavior is a courtship display that is performed by one species, Allen's Hummingbird, and not the other, Rufous Hummingbird. In this stereotyped display, called the 'pendulum display', the male flies back and forth over a female while producing distinctive sounds with his wings. The investigators will record displays from 400 birds from within a hybrid zone between these two species, and then search for genes associated with individual components of the behavior, by sequencing the genomes of these 400 birds. Understanding how one behavior splits into two will reveal a fundamental mechanism of how behavior evolves.  Additionally, this grant will train of students of diverse backgrounds, and enable outreach to the California School for the Deaf, Riverside by funding purchase of an 'acoustic camera', allowing deaf children to learn more about sound through this newly invented way of visualizing it. 

As the genetic underpinnings of how one behavior splits into two 'paramorphs', alternate forms of a previously unitary character, have not been demonstrated for any behavior, the analyses presented here aim to do so for the first time. This 3-year study has three objectives: (1) Hybrid zone mapping and cline analysis: phenotype, genotype, and selection (2): Sequence analysis of complex display behavior, and (3): Admixture mapping of behavior and morphology. Together these objectives will provide information about selection on the display traits of interest, and test the paramorph hypothesis directly, using phenotypic and genotypic data respectively. Current data indicate no fixed genetic differences between the species within coding regions of the genome, hinting that the paramorphic behavior could be driven by differences in gene regulation between the two species, rather than as the result of a paralogous gene.  Just as the modern view of morphological diversity was transformed by the study of its genetic basis, a direct assessment of the genes underlying a behavior that varies across a hybrid zone will allow one of the first tests of how a complex motor pattern has evolved. This project will build infrastructure through addition of sound, video, and specimens to the Macaulay Library at Cornell University, San Diego Natural History Museum and the SDSU Museum of Biodiversity.

por.por_cntn:
Research spanning April 1, 2017 ? Mar 31, 2023

The purpose of this study was to identify the genes (genomic regions) that are responsible for the differences in courtship display between Allen?s and Rufous Hummingbirds. Our goal was to sample the genome and courtship behavior of 400 male hummingbirds, including males of Allen?s Hummingbird, Rufous Hummingbird, and many males from a hybrid zone in between the two. The actual number of birds we sampled was 386. We found that the hybrid zone spans populations along the coast in southern Oregon (especially between Bandon and Coos Bay), as well as inland along the Klamath River in Northern California. On most males, we recorded at least 10 bouts of courtship displays.  For the birds we recorded, we then captured them, quantified their tail morphology (the tail has a different shape in the two species, and makes different sounds), and sequenced their genome. 

To analyze the courtship display sequences, we developed a new method, ?k-mer analysis?, as a way to quantify the sequences.  We found that approximately 20% of the hybrids (birds from the hybrid zone) express transgressive courtship sequences, which means that the sequences an individual hybrid expresses are outside the range of sequences that either parent species exhibits.  This is exciting because it suggests that the courtship displays are under polygenic control, because transgressive phenotypes are the result segregation of genes from two or more genes from each parent species interact in that hybrid.  

As of May 4, 2023, we have published four papers that use data from this grant: (Myers et al. 2019; Henderson and Brelsford 2020; Myers et al. 2021; Myers et al. 2022).  Another paper is in revision for the journal Heredity.  We have completed the initial GWAS analyses (Genome Wide Association mapping) but have not finished writing up these key results yet. We anticipate publishing at least 2, possibly more papers from data collected under the grant. 

Broader Impacts: This grant funded a graduate student first in his family to attend college (Brian Myers), and a postdoc of Palestinian heritage (Dr. Nadje Najar). This grant funded multiple undergraduate researchers who conducted research, including Lilly Hollingsworth, who won the Genesis award from the Animal Behavior society in 2019 for the research conducted with the support of this grant (https://www.animalbehaviorsociety.org/web/awards-genesis.php). 

This grant contributed to outreach between the Clark lab and the California School for the Deaf, specifically by providing funding for an American Sign Language translator. The Clark lab has an ?acoustic camera?, a device that dynamically paints sound sources onto a camera image in realtime. Thus, this camera provides a way for people without sensory experience of sound, a way to visualize it. Our outreach consisted of using the lab?s acoustic camera to teach 3rd-grade children who lack acoustic experiences what sound is. We ran these exercises in 2017-2019, until they were interrupted by the pandemic.  The teachers later told us that the children talked about the acoustic camera for days after our visits.
